chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A workable middle ground is for government to guarantee that everyone has access to a defined package of essential care, with protections against medical bankruptcy and coverage that follows people between jobs and life changes. Government can focus on rules that make prices and outcomes transparent, stop discrimination, and pay more for value and prevention than for volume. Within that framework, states, employers, and private plans/providers can compete and innovate on delivery and supplemental options, so people keep meaningful choice while access and affordability are secured.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Whatever the delivery model, most people agree no one should be denied essential care or face financial ruin because they get sick. A pragmatic government role is to guarantee a universal baseline of affordable, portable coverage, fund targeted help for low-income and high-need patients, and invest in prevention and public health. Government should also set clear standards and transparency rules to curb waste and surprise pricing, while leaving room for competing public and private providers to innovate and offer additional options.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Regardless of party, most people agree no one should go without essential medical care or face bankruptcy from illness, and taxpayers deserve transparent, accountable spending. A workable government role is to set and help finance a basic, portable standard of coverage—especially for children, seniors, low-income families, and people with chronic conditions—while enforcing clear rules on pricing, quality, and non-discrimination. Within that baseline, patients and employers can keep choices among competing plans and providers, with incentives for prevention, mental health care, and cost-saving innovation.
